data.title: Not possible to turn font sprites in TextField/Skin
data.body:
libGDX's inverted y-axis really sucks hard.
I am always reverting all my y-axis (because y-down is almost standard everywhere) in the matrixes but now I tried using TextField and therefore had to use a skin.
The font used in this class is rendered upside down and I can find no way to turn this font (my sprite batch is inverted).
TextField even checks if the font is flipped but it can not set to flipped?

Spritesheet has the same problem but luckily I found a workaround by looping through every region and flip it manually.

```
 for (AtlasRegion region : spritesheet.getRegions()) {
    region.flip(false, true);
}
```

It would be nice if libGDx would include something like 'boolean Gdx.graphichs.ydown' to set it globally.
I think nobody is changing the coordinate system more than once.

data.title: Simple 'remove comments from JSON' functionality in Skin & SkinLoader
data.body:
**Problem**
Under multiple times I've wanted to add comments to the JSON skin file. Why? 1) To add headlines; 2) Add simple description of UI elements, although these are not as necessary; 3) Comments for variables, such as what do the Float bar_above_below_height do, where is it used?

Currently we (me and my designer) are using google docs to document each variable, what it does etc. This is quite a lot of duplicate work and it's cumbersome to just look-up the variable, what it does, and its value. As these three attributes are stored in two different files.

An easier approach would be to document the variable inside the JSON file.

**Proposed solution**
I've changed Skin and SkinLoader to remove all comments in the JSON file before sending it to the parser, but only if the functionality is wanted. I.e. I've added another constructor to SkinLoader and a new method to Skin. These works just as before if the user doesn't make use of these methods.

**Possible enhancement**
Creating new constructors for Skin that takes a boolean (much like new SkinLoader constructor). More efficient wrapper for removing JSON comments.

**Thoughts**
I'm not sure on the naming of the variables and methods. I also see this as a first draft and suggestion. I've implemented things as simple and understandable as I could, thus they might not be the most efficient.

data.title: isKeyPressed right shift key always returns true after holding down both shift keys
data.body:
What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Hold down both left and right shift key. Gdx.input.isKeyPressed returns true for both as expected.
2. Release keys. isKeyPressed returns true for right shift key still. Furthermore, returns true for right shift until it is pressed again.

Using libgdx 0.9.9

data.title: Support creation of TextureAtlas from Pixmap
data.body:
It would be great if `TextureAtlas` could accept a `FileHandle` to an atlas and a `Pixmap`. The `Pixmap` would override the image file specified in the atlas file.

The use case here is that I have decided to encrypt and then Base64 encode all of my assets. During runtime, I decrypt and unencode it, but then I am forced to write those bytes back to a raw file before I can create a `TextureAtlas`. It would be great if I didn't have to resort to writing the bytes back to a file and then loading the newly created file.

Thank you!!

data.title: NetJavaImpl deadlock on exception in HttpResponseListener
data.body:
If exception happens in HttpResponseListener method failed(Throwable t), Lock lock in NetJavaImpl is not unlocked. Problem happens at
https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/b97b34a82af276a09bec2885854dc391ec65023d/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/net/NetJavaImpl.java#L211
(As there is no finally block to handle lock unlocking in this try, lock will stay locked)

Next time request is sent, it will deadlock at https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/b97b34a82af276a09bec2885854dc391ec65023d/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/net/NetJavaImpl.java#L150 as lock was not fully unlocked last time.

data.title: White screen render!!! What's happen with libgdx nightly 3272014??
glClear draws darker rectangle in corner
data.body:
What steps will reproduce the problem?
1. Simply call glClearColor(0.3f, 0.3f, 0.3f, 1)/glClear() in render.

What is the expected output? What do you see instead?
A filled rectangle is drawn in the corner, slightly darker than the glClear color specified; see screenshot. Note that the rectangle is a little difficult to see in the screenshot, but is very noticeable on the phone.

What version of libgdx are you using? If not using the master git branch, please try that before filing a bug.
Tried both the latest release and the current (3/27) Nightly.

Please provide any additional information below.
Reproducible on HTC One. Not reproducible in the Android emulator.

Sample source and screenshot at: https://code.google.com/p/libgdx/issues/detail?id=1726

data.title: maven missing gdx-backend-headless
data.body:
I tried to get headless into my project using gradle and couldn't get it to work.
After searching what I could have done wrong I found gdx-backend-headless is missing in both repos.
If I understand correctly sonatype is "housing" the current nightlies (1.0-Snapshot) where as mavencentral is hosting the last release (0.9.9). 

I'm not sure who's to fix this so I had to resort to posting this as an issue. It's probably just missing in a script on a buildslave, I guess?

https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots/com/badlogicgames/gdx/
http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cga%7C1%7Cgdx-backend

Edit: somehow I managed to overwrite my text with the links on the initial post, added it again to clarify.

data.title: Proper support for onAttachedToWindow and onDetachedFromWindow methods on Android 2.x
data.body:
This old PR of mine https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/859 explains why I need proper support for the mentioned methods on Android 2.3 and lower.
That PR has been dropped by a recent commit because only OpenGL ES 1.x was supported. So I had to add support for OpenGL ES 2.0 in order to successfully run my app with the last nightly builds on Android 2.x.

Relevant changes:
- Added GLSurfaceViewAPI18 and GLSurfaceView20API18 which are slightly modified copies of android.opengl.GLSurfaceView from Android 4.3 source code (API 18) and GLSurfaceView20 respectively.
- Added config property useGLSurfaceView20API18 (default false) which is effective only for API level <= 10, see createGLSurfaceView method.
- Updated AndroidApplication, AndroidGraphics, and AndroidFragmentApplication classes (the last-named not tested though, sorry).
- Removed some annoying warnings and fixed some javadoc typos.

Successfully tested on the following devices that are not working for me with the last nightly builds:
- Samsung Galaxy S Plus - Android 2.3.5 (API 10)
- LG Optimus Net - Android 2.3.4 (API 10)
- Samsung Galaxy SII - Android 2.3.3 (API 10)

Unfortunately I have no devices having both Android 2.2 and OpenGL ES 2.0. However, I'm confident that it works because the old PR works perfectly with Android 2.2 and OpenGL ES 1.x.

Finally, it looks like Daydream and LiveWallpaper classes have to be updated too, but I'm not sure it's worth. Let me know your thought.

data.title: Gwt fails to load TextureAtlas in gwt:dist
data.body:
When building an application with gwt:dist, atlas files with more than 16 entries fail to load. There is no problem in superDev mode.
- create a new project with libgdx-setup
- get a texture atlas of your choosing (like from the [libgdx tests](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/tree/master/tests/gdx-tests-android/assets/data))
- modifiy the main game with something like
  
  ``` java
          myTextures = new TextureAtlas("jump.txt");
          mySprite = myTextures.createSprite("ALIEN_JUMP_");
  ```
  
  and render it
- build the project with `gwt:dist`, copy it to a webserver and run it

Everything is ok
- modify `jump.txt` to contain more than 16 entries. (e.g. by copying the last entry, updating the index)
- Run again and it will result in an error:
  
  `GwtApplication: exception: Error reading pack file: jump.txt`
- From firefox script console:
  
  ```
  uncaught exception: Class$S92: Class$S91: Error reading pack file: jump.txt
  function f7(a,b){!a&&(a=[]);C6(a,b);return a}
  ```

data.title: Package Android JNI libraries as AAR
Fix for Music (isPlaying when paused) on iOS
data.body:
Music isPlaying() returns true on iOS when is paused.

To reproduce it, create a Music object and call play(), then pause() and finally check that the result of calling isPlaying() is true instead of false (default behaviour for Android and Desktop).

Please bear in mind that this is my first PR (not very familiar with Git yet) and, even if it's really small, I may have made a mistake, I apologise in advance if that's the case.

data.title: box2d GWT backend missing createChain(float[] vertices)
data.body:
The GWT backend ChainShape.java is missing the createChain(float[] vertices) so when I try to use it and compile to GWT I get the following error:

The method createChain(Vector2[]) in the type ChainShape is not applicable for the arguments (float[])

As it is unable to find that particular overloaded method.  This compiles to desktop and android without issue.  I am not sure if this is simply a limit of jbox2d or an actual bug.

data.title: Timer thread dies on android an is not resurrected
data.body:
I am working with the Timer utility on an android application. LibGdx version is 0.9.9 (latest stable).
The issue is caused (again) by android's weird policy with keeping static objects over app restarts.
The following is a description what causes the problem to occur:
- The app launches for the first time 
- `Timer` is creating its `TimerThread`
- The thread registers itself as a `LifecycleListener`
- The app is left (works best for me when I turn off the screen and wait for the device to be pattern-locked)
- When the app is entered again, `onCreate` is called, leading to a new `initialize()ation`=> `Gdx.app` is new, with a new list of LifecycleListeners
- `Timer.thread` is not null, for it "statically survived" => It is not being created in `Timer.instance.start` (the method itself probably isn't even called, because `instance` survived, too)
- The timer's LifecycleListener methods are not invoked either, because the listener is not registered any more  

=> The thread remains dead

For fixing the problem, I suggest setting `Timer.thread` to null in `Timer.TimerThread.pause`. If you are concerned about increased unnecessary `TimerThread` instantiations, one might as well keep a reference to the actual `Thread` which is created in `TimerThread.resume`, allowing to poll the thread's state in `Timer.instance`

**Additional information:**
Strangely, I was not able to reproduce this issue when being connected to the pc (i.e. a power source). So I suggest using adb over network when debugging 
The problem occurred with all of our team members, which is 6 persons with at least 3 different device types.

```
Name: my-gdx-game
Package: com.mygdx.game
Game class: MyGdxGame
Destination: C:\Users\Carsten\Documents\GitHub\TestGame
C:\Users\Carsten\AppData\Local\Android\android-sdk
```

The output by GradlePlugin is:

```

FAILURE: Build failed with an exception.

* Where:
Build file 'C:\Users\Carsten\Documents\GitHub\TestGame\build.gradle' line: 54
```
